Chapter on Medicine, Part Two At that time there was a sick monk who asked people in ÅšrÄvastÄ« to cook porridge.
At that time, due to circumstances, the city gate opened late, and before he could get the porridge he died.
The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It is permitted to establish a pure ground within the monastery. The white two karman should be established like this.

One should announce in the room, in the warm room, or in the walking place. A capable person should be selected from the assembly to perform the karman, either the senior-most, the next senior, or one who recites the vinaya. A capable person should perform the karman like this:
'Venerable monks, listen!
If the time has come for the assembly and the assembly consents, the assembly now establishes a certain place as a pure ground.
The announcement is like this.
'Venerable monks, listen!
The assembly now establishes a certain place as a pure ground.
Which of the elders consents to the Sangha establishing a certain place as a pure land, please remain silent. Those who do not consent, please speak.
The Sangha has already consented to establish a certain place as a pure land. Since there are no objections, this matter is thus settled.
There are four kinds of pure lands:
First, when a donor or manager is building a monastery for the Sangha, they designate a place, saying:
This place is for the Sangha to make a pure land.
Second, if a monastery is built for the Sangha but not yet given to the Sangha.
Third, if half has fences or walls, or if most does not have fences, or if none has fences, or if it has walls or moats, it is the same.
Fourth, the Sangha establishes it through a two-part formal procedure.
The monks thought:
Should a monk's room be established as a pure land?
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It should be done. Removing the rooms of monks, nuns, female novices, male novices, and female novices is also like this.
If it is a temple of ghosts and spirits, it can also be made into a pure land.
At that time, the monks did not know which places were pure lands.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It should be established.
If there is doubt about an existing pure land, it should be untied and then established.
At that time, the monks were repairing an old monastery, not knowing if they could make it into a pure land.
The Buddha said:
It can be made.
At that time, there were trees on the impure land whose branches and leaves shaded the pure land. The monks wanted to place pure things on them, not knowing if it was pure or impure.
The Buddha said:
If the roots are in the impure land, it is impure.

At that time, there was a tree root in the pure ground, and the branches and leaves shaded the impure ground. The bhiká¹£us wanted to place pure things on it, but they did not know if it was pure or not.
The Buddha said:
If the root is in the pure ground, it is pure.

At that time, there was a tree root in the impure ground, and the branches and leaves covered the pure ground. The fruits fell on the pure ground, and the bhiká¹£us did not know if it was pure or not.
The Buddha said:
If no one touches it, and it falls by itself, it is pure.
The wind blew and the rain beat it down. A monkey and various birds touched it and made it fall. They did not know if it was pure or not.
The Buddha said:
If it is not intentionally made to fall, it is pure.
The tree root was in the pure ground, and the fruit fell on the impure ground. The bhiká¹£us did not know if it was pure or not.
The Buddha said:
It is pure.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us planted cucumbers, sugarcane, vegetables, and branches and leaves on the impure ground, covering the pure ground. The bhiká¹£us did not know if it was pure or not.
The Buddha said:
It is impure.
At that time, there were people who planted cucumbers, sugarcane, and vegetables on a pure ground, covering an impure ground with branches and leaves. They did not know if it was pure or not.
The Buddha said:
It is pure.
At that time, the group of six monks ate fruits without making them pure. When the laypeople saw this, they all criticized and complained, saying:
The Åšramaá¹‡a disciples of the Buddha have no shame or disgust.
They claim:
'We know the right Dharma.'
If this is the case, where is the right Dharma?
They eat fruits without making them pure.
The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not eat fruits without making them pure. You should eat them after making them pure.
There are five kinds of purification methods for eating:
fire purification, knife purification, wound purification, bird peck purification, and seedless purification. These five kinds of purification should be eaten.
Among them, knife purification, wound purification, and bird purification should remove the seeds before eating.
Fire purification and seedless purification can be eaten entirely.
There are also five kinds of pure:
If the skin is peeled off, if the skin is stripped, if it is rotten, if it is broken, if it is dried up.
At that time the Sangha obtained a fruit grove. The Buddha said:
Allow it to be accepted.
They did not know who should take care of it.
The Buddha said:
Either the person who guards the monastery, or a novice monk, or an upÄsaka.
The person who guards it wanted to get a share. The Buddha said:
You should calculate the food and give him the price.
At that time the bhiká¹£us ate fruits without breaking them. After defecating, the seeds grew. The bhiká¹£us were afraid and said:
I ate the seeds.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
There is no offense. It is pure.
At that time the bhiká¹£us planted vegetables. After scattering the seeds themselves, they later doubted and said:
Did I plant it myself?
They did not dare to eat.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
The seeds have already changed. I allow you to eat them all.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us moved the vegetables to another place and had doubts, saying:
Did we plant them ourselves?
They did not dare to eat them.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
Because they were replanted, it is allowed to eat them.
If you plant cucumbers, sugarcane, jujubes, pears, pomegranates, Ämalaka, long peppers, ginger, and garlic, and then transplant them, you should eat them.
At that time, there was a young novice monk who held clean food across the water and could not lift it himself. The Buddha said:
It is allowed for a senior bhiká¹£u to support the novice monk to cross.
At that time, there was a young novice monk who held clean food and could not get to the shore. The Buddha said:
It is allowed for a senior bhiká¹£u to support him to get up.
At that time, there was a young novice monk who could not lift the clean food to hang it on the wall or on a hook, and he could not take it down. He told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It is allowed to place a bed or a bench under it to support him to get it up and down.
At that time the bhiká¹£us had ghee and oil jars that were uncovered. They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
Allow the attendants to cover them.
If there are no attendants, you should personally hold the lid and suspend it above. You should not touch it with your hands.
At that time the group of six bhiká¹£us ate impure vegetables. The laypeople saw this and all criticized them, saying:
The Åšramaá¹‡a disciples of the Buddha!
They have no sense of shame or disgust, and are insatiable. They take the lives of many beings, and say:
'We know the true Dharma.
' How can there be true Dharma in this?
They eat impure vegetables.
The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not eat impure vegetables. You should make them pure.
At that time they made them pure themselves. The Buddha said:
You should not make them pure yourselves. You should have the attendants make them pure.
At that time the bhiká¹£us personally held the food and had others make it pure. The Buddha said:
One should not personally touch the food and then have someone else make it pure. One should place it on the ground and have someone else make it pure.
After it was made pure, he ate it without receiving it again. The Buddha said:
One should not make it pure, then eat it without receiving it again. One should make it pure, wash one's hands, and receive the food.
After washing the root vegetables, he made them pure again. The Buddha said:
One should not wash them and then make them pure again.
This washing is itself making them pure.
At that time, a bhiká¹£u who had a prior grudge touched the pure food of another bhiká¹£u with the intention:
To cause the bhiká¹£u to obtain impure food.
That bhiká¹£u did not know whether it was pure or not.
He told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
For the one who touched it, it is impure. For the one who did not touch it, it is pure.
The one who touched it commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense.
At that time, a bhiká¹£u disliked another bhiká¹£u and touched the pure food of that bhiká¹£u by the side of a young novice monk with the intention:
It would cause the preceptor and teacher to receive impure food.
The bhiká¹£us did not know what was pure and what was impure,
and they told the Buddha. The Buddha said:
What is touched is impure, what is not touched is pure.
If touched, one commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense.
At that time, the attendants had this thought:
We will forcefully give the bhiká¹£us much food. If they do not finish it all, we will eat the leftovers.
The bhiká¹£us should verbally stop them, saying:
Do not put it here.
If they do not stop, the bhiká¹£us should move the eating utensils and grass a little away.
The bhiká¹£us did not know what was pure and what was impure,
and they told the Buddha. The Buddha said:
It is pure.
At that time, the laypeople brought food and drink to the saá¹ƒghÄrÄma and gave it to the bhiká¹£us as a reward for their service.
Later, the laypeople came and either ate themselves, took it home, or gave it to the bhiká¹£us to eat.
The bhiká¹£us were afraid and did not dare to eat, thinking:
We have been personally rewarded by our ancestors.
The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
This belongs to the donors. We allow them to wash their hands and receive food on behalf of the donors.
At that time, the sick bhiká¹£us needed porridge. The Buddha said:
We allow cooking.
If there is no one, we allow them to cook themselves.
If they cook for each other, they do not know how to cook.
The Buddha said:
We allow the attendants to wash the utensils, put water and rice in them, boil them until boiling, wash their hands and receive them, and then cook them until done.
At that time, they did not know if it was cooked or not.
The Buddha said:
You should use a ladle to look. If it flows down along the ladle, it is cooked.
If it is cooked, you should pour it into another utensil.
The one who pours the porridge also has to prepare the utensils, which is exhausting.
The Buddha said:
The one who pours the porridge should not also prepare the utensils. Another person should prepare the utensils.
If it burns your hands, you should hold tongs, a hot towel, or grass.
If a worm falls into the porridge, it should be removed.
When he burned his hand, the Buddha said:
You should use a ladle to remove it.
When they wanted to divide it, the Buddha said:
It is allowed to divide it.
They did not know with what vessel to divide it.
The Buddha said:
You may use a key, a small bowl, a medium bowl, or a ladle to divide it. If the bowl is not level, you should make a bowl stand. If it is dusty, you should make a cover.
When they did not wash the bowls and raised them, the other monks saw it and disliked it.
The Buddha said:
You should wash them clean before raising them.
After washing, they did not wash the dirt off with ash or soap beans.
The Buddha said:
You should use ash and soap beans to wash them.
After washing, they did not dry them before raising the vessels, and worms grew on them. The Buddha said:
You should not raise them without drying them. You should let them dry completely before raising them.
There were sunken holes in the vessels, and food got stuck in them. They often washed them, which wore them out.
The Buddha said:
Wash as much as can be washed. There is no offense in the rest.
The bhiká¹£us thought like this:
Is it permissible to keep overnight within the boundary, cook within the boundary, or cook oneself?
The Buddha said:
One should not keep overnight within the boundary, cook within the boundary, or cook oneself.
The bhiká¹£us thought like this:
Is it permissible to keep overnight within the boundary, cook within the boundary, or cook oneself for cooked porridge that is reheated?
The Buddha said:
One should not keep overnight within the boundary, cook within the boundary, but one may cook oneself.
The bhiká¹£us thought like this:
Is it permissible to keep overnight within the boundary, cook within the boundary, or cook oneself for medicine that is to be taken for life?
The Buddha said:
One is permitted to keep overnight within the boundary, cook within the boundary, and cook oneself for medicine that is to be taken for life.
At that time, a bhiká¹£u wanted to receive ghee but mistakenly received oil. He did not know if it was considered received.
The Buddha said:
It is not considered received.
At that time, a bhiká¹£u wanted to receive oil but mistakenly received ghee. He did not know if it was considered received.
The Buddha said:
It is not considered received.
If one wants to receive this but mistakenly receives that, he does not know if it is considered received.
The Buddha said:
It is not considered received.
There was a bhiká¹£u who forgot to receive food and then held it while traveling. After crossing the water, he remembered:
What should I do?
He then told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
If one forgets to receive food like this and then holds it while traveling, if one sees a pure person, one should place the food on the ground, wash one's hands, and receive the food again.
At that time, the World-Honored One was in the country of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«.

At that time, the world had a poor harvest and the people were starving. It was difficult to obtain alms. The bhiká¹£us placed their food in the open without covering it. Cowherds, shepherds, and thieves took it away.
The bhiká¹£us thought like this:
In times of famine, the World-Honored One should allow the Sangha to eat food stored within the boundary.
He told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
If grain is expensive, it is allowed to eat food stored within the boundary.
At that time, the monks cooked food in the open without covering it. Cowherds, shepherds, and thieves saw it and took it away. The monks thought:
In times of famine, it should be allowed to cook food within the boundary.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
In times of famine, it is allowed to cook within the boundary.
At that time, the monks had the lay people cook food, and sometimes they took some of the food or ate it all. The monks thought:
In times of famine, it should be allowed to cook food ourselves.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
In times of famine, it is allowed to cook food ourselves.
At that time, the monks were traveling on the road and saw fruit on the ground. By the time the monks found a lay person to purify the fruit, other people had already taken it away.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You may cover the fruit with grass or leaves.
But people still took it away. They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You may take it.
If you see a pure person, you should put it on the ground, wash your hands, and receive the food. The monks thought like this:
When grain is expensive, the World-Honored One should allow us to take food ourselves.
The Buddha said:
When grain is expensive, you may take food yourself.
At that time, the monks got up early, received food, put it away, and entered the village.
They returned from the invitation, and by the side of the other monks, they performed the remainder food ritual. They either shared the food or ate it all. The monks thought like this:
When grain is expensive, the World-Honored One should allow us to get up early, receive food, and eat it without performing the remainder food ritual.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
When grain is expensive, you may eat without performing the remainder food ritual.ğŸ”½At that time, the monks got up early, received food, put it away, and entered the village.

At that time, there were many well-known elder monks who entered the village to beg for food. After obtaining food, they took it to a place, ate it, and brought the remaining food back to the monastery. They then performed the remainder-of-the-food practice with the other monks and ate again. Those monks either shared the food or ate it all.
The monks thought like this:
When grain is expensive, the World-Honored One should allow us to bring food from the place of receiving and eat it without performing the remainder-of-the-food practice.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
When grain is expensive, you should be allowed to bring food from the place of receiving and eat it without performing the remainder-of-the-food practice.

At that time, the monks, after receiving food, obtained fruits such as walnuts, persimmons, jujubes, and pomegranates. They performed the remainder-of-the-food practice with the other monks, and they either shared the food or ate it all.
The monks thought like this:
When grain is expensive, the World-Honored One should allow us to eat such fruits without performing the remainder-of-the-food practice.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
When grain is expensive, it is allowed to eat such fruits without performing the non-defiled food ritual.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us had already eaten, but obtained edible water plants such as lotus roots, kapotaka, and lotus seeds. They performed the non-defiled food ritual with the bhiká¹£us, and they either shared the food or ate it all.
The bhiká¹£us thought like this:
The World-Honored One should allow us to eat such edible water plants without performing the non-defiled food ritual when grain is expensive.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
When grain is expensive, it is allowed to eat such edible water plants without performing the non-defiled food ritual after having already eaten.
At that time, the grain in the world returned to being cheap. The World-Honored One knew but deliberately asked Ä€nanda:
When grain was expensive, out of compassion for the bhiká¹£us I allowed eight things:

Sleeping together in the same boundary, cooking within the boundary, cooking oneself, taking food with one's own hands, accepting food before dawn, bringing back leftover food from a place where one has eaten, eating walnuts and other fruits, edible things in water, and eating after one has finished a meal without performing the ritual for leftover food.
Do the bhiká¹£us still eat these things on purpose?
They replied:
We eat them on purpose.
The Buddha said:
You should not eat them.
If you eat them, you should be dealt with according to the rules.
At that time, the monks' kitchen was damaged. The monks supported it with wood. The wood was on an impure ground. They were unsure if it was pure or not.
The Buddha said:
It is pure. You can eat.
At night, the food was moved and fell onto an impure ground. The monks did not know if it was pure or not.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It is pure.
At night, the food was moved and fell between a pure and impure ground. The monks did not know if it was pure or not.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It is pure.
At that time, a dog carried food from a clean place to an unclean place. The monks did not know if it was clean or not.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It is clean. If it is carried by other evil beasts or birds, it is also like this.
At that time, a monk disliked another monk and moved his food to an unclean place, thinking:
Let him not get to eat it.
The monk did not know if it was clean or not.
He told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
If it is touched, it is unclean, and one commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense.
If it is not touched, it is clean.
At that time, a monk disliked another monk and had this intention:
Let me touch the clean ground to make him get an unclean one.
The monks did not know if it was clean or not.
They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
If it is touched, it is unclean, and one commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense.
If it is not touched, it is clean.
At that time, a guest monk came, looking for a pure place to put his food. Before reaching the pure place, the morning light appeared. He did not know whether it was pure or not.
He told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It is pure.
Those who wish to go far should do the same.
At that time, the group of six monks kept measures such as a pint, a peck, a bushel, and a scale. The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not keep them.
At that time, the monks obtained sesame, rice, soybeans, mung beans, barley, and wheat, and wanted to measure them themselves. They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You are allowed to measure them with your hand, or with a key, a bowl, or a small bowl. Use these utensils to measure the size and take them as a bushel or a peck.
At that time, the monks obtained ghee, oil, honey, and molasses, and wanted to weigh them. They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You are allowed to carve wood to make a scale of ounces and pounds, and set a limit of four or five ounces, taking them as a jin (unit of weight).
They made the upper rooms into the purification place, and the ghee, oil, and grease stained or smoked the rooms. They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not make the upper rooms into the purification place. You should make the lower rooms into the purification place.
The monks obtained fruits.
The Buddha said:
You should divide them one by one. If there are not enough, you should remember the order. If you obtain more later, you should continue to give.
If you obtain many fruits, you should give four or five to each person, or give a handful, or a key, or a bowl, or give to those who can eat them.
If there are still leftovers, you should give more.
At that time, they gave to laypeople and non-Buddhists. The Buddha said:
You should not give to non-Buddhists and laypeople.

Later, the monks were afraid and did not dare to give to their parents, sick people, children, pregnant women, those in prison, or laypeople who came to the monastery. They told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
One should give to such a person, and if there is any left, one should press it to extract the juice and drink it.
At that time, they needed pressing equipment, and the Buddha said:
It is allowed to keep it.
If the juice has not yet boiled and does not intoxicate people, one may drink it;
if it intoxicates people, one should not drink it. If one drinks it, one should be dealt with according to the rules.
At that time, the World-Honored One was in Vaishali.
At that time, the Sangha had many offerings of food and drink. The bhiká¹£us suffered from dampness and told the Buddha. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to make emetic and purgative medicine. If they need soup and gruel, give them soup and gruel. If they need the meat of wild birds, give it to them.
At that time, there was a bhiká¹£u who suffered from a headache. The doctor instructed him to pour water up his nose. The Buddha said:
It is allowed.
They did not know what to pour.
The Buddha said:
Pour ghee, oil, and fat.
They did not know how to pour.
The Buddha said:
It is allowed to soak sheep's wool, silk, and bird feathers in oil, and then drip it into the nose.
The Buddha said:
You may make a nasal douche tube.
They used precious materials to make the tube, the Buddha said:
You may not use precious materials.
You may use bone, ivory, horn, iron, copper, tin, lead, reed, bamboo, or wood.
They did not wash it after use and put it away, the Buddha said:
You may not not wash it after use and put it away.
After washing it, they did not dry it and insects grew in it, the Buddha said:
You may not not dry it after washing it, you should dry it before putting it away.
At that time a bhiká¹£u had a headache, the doctor instructed him to use a nasal douche, the medicine did not enter, the Buddha said:
You may massage the head, or the big toe, or stuff the nose with ghee.
At that time a bhiká¹£u had a wind illness, the doctor instructed him to use smoke, the Buddha said:
You may use smoke.
At that time they needed a smoking tube, the Buddha said:
You may make them.
They made them with precious materials, the Buddha said:
You should not make cases with precious materials.
You may use bone, ivory, horn, iron, copper, tin, lead, or wood.
If you are worried about fire burning and smoke coming out, you may use iron.
If you are worried that the cases will fall off, the Buddha said:
You may make a bag to store them.
Holding them in the hand is not firm, the Buddha said:
You should make a belt to fasten them to your shoulder.
They needed pill medicine, the Buddha said:
You may make them.
Holding them in the hand is not firm, they should be stored in a fragrant case.

At that time there was a bhiká¹£u with a sore, a doctor taught him to make a sore ointment, the Buddha said:ğŸ”½You may make it, if the sore is ripe, you should break it with a knife and apply the medicine.
From now on, you are allowed to break sores with a knife, if the sore smells bad you should wash it.
If using a decoction of roots, stems, leaves, flowers, or fruits, or when washing with urine, wash with the hand and the pain will be alleviated, or wash with bird feathers.
If the medicine drips, use an object to block the four sides.
If suffering from dryness, apply oil, if dripping above, cover with an object, if the wound is smelly, apply fragrance.
At that time the bhiká¹£us had malaria, the Buddha said:
Allow thick clothes to be used as a cover, if still cold, use bedding and felt blankets to cover above, if the cold does not stop, a bhiká¹£u should sleep together.
They were afraid and did not dare to sleep with the sick person, the Buddha said:
Allow sleeping together with the sick person.
At that time a layperson who was sick came to the monastery, the bhiká¹£us took care of him, the bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, the Buddha said:
Use skillful means to send him away, if he praises the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, and can do things, do them for him.
The sick person died, and the bhiká¹£us were afraid and did not dare to discard [the body]. The World-Honored One said:
You should not discard it.
The laypeople died, and the bhiká¹£us told the Buddha. The Buddha said:
You should discard it for the sake of purifying the saá¹ƒgha's monastery.
At that time, the group of six shaved the hair in three places. The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not shave the hair in three places.
At that time, the group of six looked at each other's tails, asking who had a long tail and who had a short tail.
What medicine did they apply?
The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not look at each other's tails, ask about their length, or what medicine they apply.
At that time, the group of six poured ghee and oil into the anus. The Buddha said:
You should not pour [them in].
They instructed others to pour [them in]. The Buddha said:
You should not instruct others to pour [them in].

At that time, the bhiká¹£us had completed the summer retreat in the north. Their bodies were emaciated and their complexions haggard. They went to the Jetavana monastery to where the Buddha was. They bowed their heads at his feet and then sat to one side.
The World-Honored One asked the visiting bhiká¹£us:
Was your dwelling place peaceful and harmonious?
Were you not exhausted from begging for food?
They replied:
Our dwelling place was peaceful and harmonious, without strife. But in that country there was no porridge. Because we could not get porridge, our strength was weak.
The Buddha asked:
What kind of food do you usually eat in that country?
They replied:
In that country we usually eat cakes.
The Buddha said:
You are allowed to eat cakes.

At that time, a horse trader from the country of Varanasi came to the state of Shravasti, wanting to make cakes and bean paste for the assembly of monks. He gave paste and paste containers, salt and salt containers, sour wine and sour wine bottles, wooden scoops and cups, spoons and ladles, oil and cup bowls, and food roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruits, oil, sesame, black honey, and fine powder. The Buddha said:
All are allowed to receive food.
The monks thought like this:
I don't know if this porridge is food or not,
if it's an invitation or not,
if it's a full meal or not.
The Buddha said:
If it's held on grass without a trace, it's not food, not an invitation, not a full meal.
At that time, the monks thought like this:
Is drinking boiled rice water food or not?
Is it an invitation or not?
Is it a sufficient meal or not?
The Buddha said:
If it is not drinking the dregs, it is not a meal, not an invitation, and not a sufficient meal.
At that time the monks thought like this:
I do not know if cakes are a meal or not, if it is an invitation or not, and if it is a sufficient meal or not.
The Buddha said:
It is not a meal, and so on, up to it is not a sufficient meal.
At that time the group of six monks ate food mixed with salt that had been stored overnight.
The Buddha said:
You should not eat food mixed with salt that has been stored overnight.
At that time UpÄli bared his right shoulder, touched his right knee to the ground, put his palms together, and said to the Buddha:
What are the medicines that should be taken for life?
